page.title: 11PHEASANT REARING PART 1
page.content: {Mr Cocker is a gamekeeper at Moorhouse {Farm which is to the south of the {Helperby to Raskelf road.In the big {pen outside there are 160 hens and 40 {cock pheasants.When the eggs have been {laid they are collected and put into {an incubator.There they stay for 20 {days and are turned three times a day. {The incubator holds 3,000 eggs and the {temperature must be 100 degrees {Celsius. { After 20 days the eggs are put into {the settling trays.After that they go {into the hatcher for 4 days.Once they {have hatched they are fed three times {a day and are put into huts outside. {These huts have special lamps to keep {the pheasants warm.Each week they go {into different huts until they are {five to six weeks old.They are then {let out into the woods where they are {kept in release pens. }
